docs.lead_paragraph: The global financial crisis knocked Germany and the rest of the world badly off course this year. Yet as the country grinds toward national elections on Sunday, the campaign's most notable absence has been a debate over the direction and future of Europe's largest economy. Neither Chancellor Angela Merkel nor her challenger from the center-left, Foreign Minister Frank-Walter Steinmeier, has delved deeply into policy matters, preferring to focus on personality and politics. And neither is temperamentally inclined to attack the other.

headline.main: Debate on Economy Muted As Germans Prepare to Vote

docs.abstract: Many analysts say German election campaign has avoided debate over economic policy because choices Germany faces are bound to polarize country that deeply values consensus; many economists predict Germany will settle into phase of slow growth or stagnation in coming months and years; debate over possible corrective measures offers little political advantage to either Chancellor Angela Merkel or challenger Frank-Walter Steinmeier (M)
docs.snippet: The most important reason for the absence of any real economic debate, many analysts say, is that the stark choices Germany faces are bound to polarize the country.

docs.lead_paragraph: Liberal Senate Democrats will push to add a government-run insurance program to the health care bill in the Finance Committee on Friday, setting off a potentially explosive debate with Republicans who view the idea as a step toward ''socialized medicine.'' Senators John D. Rockefeller IV, right, Democrat of West Virginia, and Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, said Thursday that they would propose the so-called public option because efforts to revamp the health system and cover the uninsured would fail without it.
docs.abstract: Liberal Senate Democrats will push to add government-run insurance program to health care legislation taking shape in Finance Committee; move could set off debate with Republicans, who view idea as step toward 'socialized medicine'; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Liberal Senate Democrats will push to add a government-run insurance program to the health care bill in the Finance Committee on Friday, setting off a potentially explosive debate with Republicans who view the idea as a step toward ''socialized...

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama scored a big victory on Thursday as the Senate Finance Committee rejected a proposal to require pharmaceutical companies to give bigger discounts to Medicare on drugs dispensed to older Americans with low incomes. The victory came at the expense of senators in Mr. Obama's own party who had championed the proposal. The vote, in effect, upheld a deal reached in June by the White House and the drug industry, which saw the agreement as a possible way to avoid more onerous requirements that might be imposed by Congress.

headline.main: Senate Panel Rejects Bid to Add Drug Discount

docs.abstract: Pres Obama scores big victory as Senate Finance Committee rejects proposal to require pharmaceutical companies to give bigger discounts to Medicare on drugs dispensed to older Americans with lower incomes; vote effectively upholds deal reached in June between Obama administration and drug companies; proposal called for more than $100 billion in rebates over 10 years; vote is defeat for senators in Obama's own party who have championed measure; photos (M)
docs.snippet: President Obama scored a big victory on Thursday as the Senate Finance Committee rejected a proposal to require pharmaceutical companies to give bigger discounts to Medicare on drugs dispensed to older Americans with low incomes.     The victory came...

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and JACKIE CALMES; Carl Hulse contributed reporting

docs.lead_paragraph: On the Economix blog, our colleague David Leonhardt rounds up arguments in support of the health care amendment offered by Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, which would allow all Americans to shop for and buy their medical insurance on the new insurance exchanges, or marketplaces, that are being proposed in the various bills in Congress. Right now, the various bills place limits on who would be able to shop on the exchanges. Read the post.

headline.main: On Behalf of Senator Wyden's Bill to Give Open Access to Insurance Exchanges

docs.abstract: Arguments in support of the Wyden amendment, which would give all -- not just a few -- access to health insurance exchanges.
docs.snippet: Arguments in support of the Wyden amendment, which would give all -- not just a few -- access to health insurance exchanges.

docs.lead_paragraph: Liberal Senate Democrats on Friday will push to add a government-run insurance program to the health care bill in the Finance Committee, setting off a potentially explosive debate with Republicans who view the idea as a step toward "socialized medicine."

headline.main: Schumer and Rockefeller Plan to Push for Public Insurance Option

docs.abstract: The liberal Senate Democrats Rockefeller and Schumer on Friday plan to push to add a government-run insurance program to the health care bill in the Finance Committee, setting off a potentially explosive debate with Republicans
docs.snippet: The liberal Senate Democrats Rockefeller and Schumer on Friday plan to push to add a government-run insurance program to the health care bill in the Finance Committee, setting off a potentially explosive debate with Republicans

docs.lead_paragraph: One big, underappreciated question about the Senate's health reform deliberations is whether the proposal that results will give people more freedom to choose their own insurer.
docs.abstract: The Senate is considering whether families should have more freedom to choose their health insurer.
docs.snippet: The Senate is considering whether families should have more freedom to choose their health insurer.

docs.lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH-The White House, after initially saying that President Obama was too busy with overhauling the health insurance system to commit to going to Copenhagen to push for Chicago's 2016 Olympic bid, now says that he "absolutely" might go.

headline.main: Obama May Head to Copenhagen, After All

docs.abstract: The White House, after initially saying that President Obama was too busy with overhauling the health insurance system to commit to going to Copenhagen to push for Chicago's 2016 Olympic bid, now says that he "absolutely" might go.
docs.snippet: The White House, after initially saying that President Obama was too busy with overhauling the health insurance system to commit to going to Copenhagen to push for Chicago's 2016 Olympic bid, now says that he "absolutely" might go.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama's deal with the drug manufacturers is intact. For now.

headline.main: Drug Industry Deal Survives Senate Committee Vote

docs.abstract: An amendment that would overturn a deal with the drug industry was voted down in the Senate Finance Committee on Thursday afternoon.
docs.snippet: An amendment that would overturn a deal with the drug industry was voted down in the Senate Finance Committee on Thursday afternoon.

docs.lead_paragraph: People with pre-existing conditions who have been turned down for health insurance could get a lifeline under the Senate Finance Committee's proposed health plan: they would be eligible to sign up for a high-risk insurance pool that would accept all applicants, regardless of health status.
docs.abstract: The Baucus bill offers up high-risk insurance pools as a solution for people denied coverage due to pre-existing conditions. But the pools haven't worked well at the state level, experts say.
docs.snippet: The Baucus bill offers up high-risk insurance pools as a solution for people denied coverage due to pre-existing conditions. But the pools haven't worked well at the state level, experts say.

docs.lead_paragraph: Look out, the gloves are coming off.

headline.main: Private Medicare Plans Are at Center of Senate Finance Fight

docs.abstract: Commercially provided Medicare Advantage plans continue to be at the center of the Senate Finance fight.
